case_name: Appellant v. Bombay Bullion Association Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 56 of 1962 filed by special leave from Bombay High Court judgment dated March 3, 4, 1958 in Appeal No. 27 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 56 of 1962. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated March 3, 4, 1958 of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 27 of 1957.

facts.text: Appellant is a member of the first respondent, the Bombay Bullion Association Ltd., and carries on business as a bullion merchant.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a member of the first respondent-the Association and carries on business as a bullion merchant.

facts.text: Government of Bombay sanctioned bye-laws of the Association by notification dated March 14, 1949 under s. 6 of Bombay Forward Contracts Control Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: By a notification dated March 14, 1949, the Government of Bombay in exercise of the powers conferred by s. 6 of the Bombay Forward Contracts Control Act, 1947  Bombay Act LXIV of 1947  sanctioned by the bye-laws

facts.text: Appellant defaulted in performing his contract as a seller on settlement day February 3, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: the regularity of a purchase effected by the Association purporting to act under its bye-laws, of a quantity of silver at the risk of the appellant, on the footing that he had defaulted

facts.text: Association purchased silver at appellant's risk and claimed Rs. 1,37,880-12-0 from him.

anchor.surface_text: in performing his contract as a seller on February 3, 1953 which was a settlement day. The Association made this purchase treating the appellant as a defaulter and claimed

facts.text: Appellant paid Rs. 1,37,880-12-0 on February 5, 1953 under protest.

anchor.surface_text: from him the difference which amounted to Rs. 1,37,880-12-0. The appellant paid this sum when demanded on the 5th February under protest

facts.text: Appellant filed suit on next day after payment (February 6, 1953) against Association and Directors for refund.

anchor.surface_text: but on the next day he filed the suit out of which the present appeal arises against the Association and its Directors for its refund on the ground that the purchase

facts.text: Appellant did not dispute his own default in tendering bullion on settlement day.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant did not dispute that he defaulted in performing his obligation to tender the bullion of which he was the forward seller on the settlement day

facts.text: Appellant attacked purchase claiming purchasers had not fulfilled obligations under bye-laws.

anchor.surface_text: as he was bound to do under the relevant bye- laws but the point on which he attacked the purchase was that no purchase could be made unless

facts.text: Suit tried before Coyajee J. on Original Side of Bombay High Court, who found no default by purchasers and dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was tried before Coyajee J. on the Original Side of the Bombay High Court. The learned Judge recorded a finding that there had been no default

facts.text: Appellant's appeal to Division Bench of Bombay High Court dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: on the part of the purchasers and he, therefore, dismissed the suit. An appeal preferred by the appellant to a Division Bench also failed

facts.text: Concurrent finding of both lower courts that each purchaser's cheque was paid into Clearing House on February 3, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: there is a concurrent finding of fact of both the Courts that each one of the cheques of the several purchasers was, paid into the Clearing House on February 3, 1953

facts.text: Settlement day (Vaida day) postponed from February 2, 1953 to February 3, 1953 by Board under bye-law 32.

anchor.surface_text: the settlement for the Maha Vaida was originally fixed to February 2, 1953. ... It was in exercise of this power that the Vaida day was postponed from February 2, 1953 to February 3, 1953.

facts.text: Bank of Baroda appointed as Clearing House under bye-law 120.

anchor.surface_text: Under the powers thus conferred the Bank of Baroda which opened a branch at the premises of the Association were appointed as the Clearing House.

facts.text: Total outstanding sale of 1897 bars of silver on February 3, 1953 settlement.

anchor.surface_text: there was a total outstanding sale of 1897 bars of silver with, of course, corresponding purchases of the same number.

facts.text: Appellant had outstanding sale of 853 bars and failed to submit delivery orders.

anchor.surface_text: Sellers of 1,004 bars gave delivery orders as required by bye-laws 137 and 137-A but the appellant who had an outstanding sale of 853 bars failed

facts.text: Purchasers required to pay Rs. 88,31,050 by February 3, 1953 under bye-law 137-B.

anchor.surface_text: The purchasers of the 1,897 bars had, under the bye-laws, to submit their Clearance Sheets and make payments into the Clearing House ... total sum of Rs. 88,31,050

facts.text: Directors extended time for payment and Clearance Sheets to 7 P.M. on February 3, 1953 due to heavy volume and clerks' strike.

anchor.surface_text: the Directors of the Association passed a resolution extending the time for payment and delivery of Clearance Sheets beyond the usual banking hours to 7 P.m. on the 3rd February.

facts.text: Bank of Baroda confirmed receipt of all Rs. 88,31,050 on February 4, 1953 statement.

anchor.surface_text: the Bank of Baroda Ltd. Clearing House submitted a statement on February 4, 1953 stating that all the payments totalling Rs. 88,31,050 had been received

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with High Court that purchasers fulfilled obligations under bye-law 137-B.

anchor.surface_text: We thus reach the conclusion that except the last payment which was not quite regular but whose irregularity is not material, all the other payments were substantially, if not literally, in accordance

facts.text: Appellant admitted non-compliance with bye-law 137-A.

anchor.surface_text: As stated earlier, it is not common ground that the appellant did not carry out his obligations under this bye- law.

facts.text: No evidence of mala fides by Directors; plea rejected by trial judge and not pressed.

anchor.surface_text: There was nothing in the evidence in support of this plea and Coyajee, J. having negatived it, the same does not appear to have been pressed before the Division Bench.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated March 3, 4, 1958

concepts.unlisted_description: Obligations of purchasers on clearance day.

anchor.surface_text: Bye-law 137-B whose proper construction is raised by this appeal deals with the obligations of members whose Clearance Sheet shows outstanding purchases. It reads 137-B. A member whose Clearance Sheet shows outstanding purchases will submit to the Clearing House with his Clearance Sheet a cheque certified good for payment or a demand draft on a Bank or a Banks payslip or cash for an amount sufficient to pay for all his outstanding purchases at the rate fixed by the Association.

Bye-law 32 of the Association empowers the Board to fix the days of settlement in these terms 32.  1  The settlement days shall be fixed by the Board or the Sub-Committee appointed by it keeping in mind the provisions or these Rules and bye-laws. but cl.  3  of the same bye-law empowers the Board if of opinion that circumstances exist which require an alteration of days so fixed by cl.  1  the Board -may postpone such settlement day for a period number exceeding 5 days.

concepts.interpretation: Empowers Board to postpone settlement day; postponement from Feb 2 to 3 upheld.

anchor.surface_text: Bye-law 120 makes provision for the establishment of a Clearing House for effecting a settlement on the Vaida days. This bye-law reads Clearing House -A Clearing House shall be established under the jurisdiction of the Board to act as an ordinary agent of the members for settling forward transactions effected between members in gold, silver and sovereigns by exchanging delivery orders as also for making payment of the amounts of difference through the Clearing House. Under the powers thus conferred the Bank of Baroda which opened a branch at the premises of the Association were appointed as the Clearing House.

concepts.interpretation: Establishes Clearing House; Bank of Baroda appointed.

anchor.surface_text: Bye-law 127 specifies the powers and duties of the Clearing House Committee and this runs Powers and duties of the Clearing House Committee - The Clearing House Committee shall settle forms of clearing sheets, delivery forms, Kaplis  slips  relating to payment of differences and delivery of goods and other necessary documents for being used for the work relating to the Clearing House and every member shall have to use the said forms or other forms of the same size and with similar writing.

concepts.interpretation: Refund of margin money; early refund held proper as conditions ceased to exist.

issues.text: This appeal, by special leave, raises for consideration a very short point regarding the proper construction of bye-law 137-B of the Bombay Bullion Association Ltd., ... and in particular whether on the facts established in this case the requirements of the said bye-law has been satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by special leave, raises for consideration a very short point regarding the proper construction of bye-law 137-B of the Bombay Bullion Association Ltd., which will hereafter be referred to as the Association and in particular whether on the facts established in this case the requirements of the said bye- law has been satisfied.

issues.text: whether those who made forward purchases for this Vaida had fulfilled their obligations under the bye-laws.

anchor.surface_text: This leads us to the main question which it would be apparent from the above narrative is whether those who made forward purchases for this Vaida had fulfilled their obligations under the bye-laws.

issues.text: the point on which he attacked the purchase was that no purchase could be made unless the forward purchasers for that settlement had fulfilled the terms of their obligations under the bye-laws

anchor.surface_text: but the point on which he attacked the purchase was that no purchase could be made unless the forward purchasers for that settlement had fulfilled the terms of their obligations under the bye-laws and that as they had failed to do so, the Association had no right to effect a purchase on behalf and for the benefit of such defaulting purchasers.

issues.text: whether the several parties who figured as purchasers on the Vaida day had or had not paid in their cheques into the Clearing House of the Association on February 3, 1953 as they were bound to do under the bye-laws

anchor.surface_text: in particular whether the several parties who figured as purchasers on the Vaida day had or had not paid in their cheques into the Clearing House of the Association on February 3, 1953 as they were bound to do under the bye- laws, it is not necessary for us to go into this matter because there is a concurrent finding of fact of both the Courts

issues.text: whether the Director[s] of the Association had acted mala fide in permitting certain infractions of bye-laws on the 3rd February by purchasers who would otherwise be in default

anchor.surface_text: This relates to a plea by the appellant that the Directors of the Association had acted mala fide in permitting certain infractions of bye- laws on the 3rd February by purchasers who would otherwise be in default and treating them as if they had fulfilled their obligations.

issues.text: whether certain of the purchasers had made payments into the Clearing House of the amounts payable by them in any of the permitted modes.

anchor.surface_text: The question raised in this appeal, relates to whether certain of the purchasers had made payments into the Clearing House of the amounts payable by them in any of the permitted modes.

issues.text: whether payments into the Clearing House Account by cheques drawn on the Banking account at this branch were made after [banking hours] ... could [they] be treated as cash

anchor.surface_text: On February 3, 1953 the banking hours ended at 2.30 P.m. and several of the payments into the Clearing House Account by cheques drawn on the Banking account at this branch were made after that hour. It was, therefore, contended that even if there was enough money in the accounts of the several members to meet the cheques drawn by them, still their cheques could not be treated as cash as the banking hours had passed.

issues.text: whether a strict and literal construction of the bye-law was called for ... or ... merely a substantial compliance with it in the sense of the Clearing House having received payment would satisfy the rule.

anchor.surface_text: having regard to the consequences flowing from a payment or non-payment on the terms of the bye-laws a strict and literal construction of the bye-law was called for and that the Courts should so construe the bye-law and hold that a literal and not merely a substantial compliance with it in the sense of the Clearing House having received payment would satisfy the rule.

issues.text: whether cheques drawn on an account in a branch of a bank [paid into same branch] ... [require] certification ... or ... really a payment in cash.

anchor.surface_text: we should consider that the proper view to take of the payment would be that it is really a payment in cash. ... We consider these observations apposite and hold that where a payment was made by a cheque drawn on an account with the Bullion Exchange Sub-branch and the amount represented by that cheque was transferred to the Clearing House Account of the Association it is virtually a payment in cash, though in form a payment by cheque.

issues.text: whether the margin money could have been returned only on the 4th and that the Association acted improperly in refunding the amounts to the purchasers on the 3rd itself

anchor.surface_text: Bye-law 33-C (2) deals with the refund of margin money ... On this the appellants case was that the margin money could have been returned only on the 4th and that the Association acted improperly in refunding the amounts to the purchasers on the 3rd itself to enable them to utilise that money for the purpose of making their payments towards the settlement.

issues.text: whether [for cheque from Fort branch paid into Bullion Hall Sub-branch] ... the payment could be treated as by a cheque which is certified as good for payment.

anchor.surface_text: The Bullion Hall Sub-branch of the bank accepts that cheque and credits it to the Association after ascertaining that the drawer of the cheque has enough funds at the Fort branch for meeting that cheque. The only question is whether the payment could be treated as by a cheque which is certified as good for payment.

issues.text: whether [the last payment by cheque on Bank of India] could certainly not be within bye-law 137-B.

holdings.text: All the other payments were substantially, if not literally, in accordance with the requirements of bye-law 137-B and in consequence the purchase made by the Directors at the risk of the appellant was legal and justified under the bye-laws.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Court applies purposive interpretation to bye-law 137-B in commercial context, equating bank-verified cheques to certified or cash; accepts concurrent factual findings; minor irregularity immaterial.

holdings.text: There is a concurrent finding of fact of both the Courts that each one of the cheques of the several purchasers was paid into the Clearing House on February 3, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: there is a concurrent finding of fact of both the Courts that each one of the cheques of the several purchasers was, paid into the Clearing House on February 3, 1953

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supreme Court defers to concurrent factual findings of lower courts under appellate review standards; no interference needed.

holdings.text: The Directors of the Association had not acted mala fide in permitting certain infractions of bye-laws.

anchor.surface_text: There was nothing in the evidence in support of this plea and Coyajee, J. having negatived it, the same does not appear to have been pressed before the Division Bench.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence supports plea; rejected by trial court and not pressed on appeal.

holdings.text: There was nothing illegal in the bank functioning after 2.30 P.M. for Clearing House purposes; extension to 7 P.M. valid.

anchor.surface_text: the Directors of the Association passed a resolution extending the time for payment and delivery of Clearance Sheets beyond the usual banking hours to 7 P.m. on the 3rd February.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Extension not contrary to statute; beneficial to members; bank verified funds despite after-hours.

holdings.text: Refund of margin money on February 3 proper as conditions ceased to exist; irrelevant to bye-law 137-B compliance.

anchor.surface_text: Bye-law 33-C (2) deals with the refund of margin money ... We do not see any substance in this complaint, nor do we see any relevance

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bye-law 33-C permits refund when conditions cease; postponement does not shift refund date rigidly; does not affect payment validity.

holdings.text: Payment by cheque drawn on account with the Bullion Exchange Sub-branch and transferred to Clearing House Account is virtually a payment in cash.

anchor.surface_text: We consider these observations apposite and hold that where a payment was made by a cheque drawn on an account with the Bullion Exchange Sub-branch and the amount represented by that cheque

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Privy Council precedent on commercial equivalence of intra-branch transfers to cash; no need for formal certification.

holdings.text: Cheque drawn on Fort branch, verified for sufficient funds by Bullion Hall Sub-branch, satisfies requirements of a cheque certified as good for payment within bye-law 137-B.

anchor.surface_text: The Bullion Hall Sub-branch of the bank accepts that cheque and credits it to the Association after ascertaining that the drawer of the cheque has enough funds at the Fort branch

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bank verification equates to certification; purposive view in commercial context.

holdings.text: Last payment by cheque on Bank of India not within bye-law 137-B but irregularity immaterial as concerns only 25 bars.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Concedes irregularity but de minimis given scale (25/853 bars); does not invalidate overall purchase.

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was, in this connection, placed on the observations of the Privy Council in Gaden v.The Newfoundland Savings Bank 1  where it is stated The only effect of the certifying is to give the cheque additional currency by showing on the face that it is drawn in good faith on funds sufficient to meet its payment, and by adding to the credit of the drawer that of the bank on which it is drawn.

precedents.case_name: Gaden v The Newfoundland Savings Bank
precedents.cited_proposition: The only effect of the certifying is to give the cheque additional currency by showing on the face that it is drawn in good faith on funds sufficient to meet its payment, and by adding to the credit of the drawer that of the bank on which it is drawn.

precedents.citation: Bank of Baroda v. Punjab National Bank 2

anchor.surface_text: Reference was also made to the judgment of Lord Wright in Bank of Baroda v. Punjab National Bank 2  where the history of certification or marking of cheques in India is dealt with. We do not, however, derive any assistance from these decisions on the point now in controversy.

precedents.case_name: Bank of Baroda v Punjab National Bank
precedents.cited_proposition: history of certification or marking of cheques in India

precedents.citation: Arsene Larocque v. Hyacin the Beauchmin, 1

anchor.surface_text: The Privy Council had, in Arsene Larocque v. Hyacin the Beauchmin, 1  to consider whether the payment a company by receipts given by it on account of the purchase price of the property which they sold was a payment in cash.

precedents.cited_proposition: whether certain payments constitute payment in cash

anchor.surface_text: Lord Macnaghten quoted with approval the following from the judgment of James L. J. in Spargos 2 case It was said by the Lord Chancellor, and we entirely concurred with him, that it could not be right to put any construction upon that section (s. 25 of the Companies Act, 1867) which would lead to such an absurd and un- justifiable result as this, than in exchange of cheques would not be payment in cash, or that an order upon a banker to transfer money from the account of a company would not be a payment in cash.

precedents.cited_proposition: exchange of cheques or banker transfer constitutes payment in cash; setting off demands without physical transfer of money
precedents.cited_holding: It could not be right to put any construction upon that section which would lead to such an absurd result as that an exchange of cheques would not be payment in cash, or that an order upon a banker to transfer money from the account of a company would not be a payment in cash.
